awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Physics of Magnetized Dusty Plasmas
awd_abstract_narration:
Plasmas (i.e., charged, ionized gases) are pervasive.  From stellar nurseries to the Earth's ionosphere, plasmas represent a fourth state of matter that is the most common form of matter in the visible universe.  Moreover, a phenomenon known as a "dusty" or "complex" plasma is formed when charged particulate matter, such as dust or ices, becomes incorporated in the plasma environment.  In space, phenomena such as in comet tails or the rings of Saturn are examples of dusty plasmas.  Closer to Earth, control over particulates in plasmas are important in high-technology and microelectronic fabrication.  In both astrophysical and technological plasmas, the presence of magnetic fields can have a profound influence on the properties of the plasma.  This research project supports a new, state-of-the-art, multi-user, superconducting, high-magnetic device to understand the basic properties of a strongly magnetized plasmas and magnetized dusty plasma.  The intellectual merit of this work is that it will enable the study of new regimes of plasma physics and dusty plasma physics that have not been accessible in previous experiments.  The main project goal is to investigate how the structural, thermal, charging, and stability properties of a dusty plasma evolve as the system is taken from an unmagnetized state through a progression of regimes where first the electrons, then the ions, and then charged microparticles become magnetized.

The broader impact of this work is substantial.  This project is a direct collaboration among three US universities (Auburn University, The University of Iowa, and University of California-San Diego) that perform leading research in the field of dusty plasmas.  The researchers from these three organizations will coordinate a broad team of collaborators representing universities, national laboratories, and international partners.  And, this project will provide excellent opportunities to train the next generation of plasma scientists through the training of graduate and undergraduate students as well as providing partnerships with dusty plasma researchers at predominantly undergraduate institutions.

por.por_cntn:
This project was for collaborative research conducted by Auburn University, The University of Iowa, and the University of California, San Diego. The research was an experimental project using an NSF funded device known as the Magnetized Dusty Plasma Experiment (MDPX) built at Auburn University. The award funded work of the University of Iowa PI on the MDPX device at Auburn University, and funded undergraduate physics majors who performed supporting experiments at the University of Iowa.

A large fraction of the material in the universe is gas in the ionized state in which one or more electrons have been separated from the atom. This state of matter is known as a plasma, and is of fundamental interest because the electrons and ions interact with each other via electrical forces. This distinguishes a plasma from an ordinary gas in which the gas atoms interact like colliding billiard balls. Most of the solid matter in the universe is in the form of small dust particles – particles with sizes in the range of a thousandth of a millimeter. Often the dust particles are in regions where there is also plasma, which gets attached to the dust giving the particles an electrical charge. We call the combination of dust and plasma, dusty plasma. Comets are surrounded by dusty plasma, and some of the dust in Saturn’s rings is also in the dusty plasma state. The regions of the universe where stars are born are also examples of dusty plasmas. There are also a number of technological applications of dusty plasmas, so the study of dusty plasmas is of importance both from a basic science and applied science point of view. The motion of charged particles can also be influenced by magnetic fields. Magnetic fields are routinely used to trap and confine plasmas. Because the dust particles are relatively massive, a very strong magnetic field (at least 10 times stronger than the magnets used to hold notes on a refrigerator door) is needed to influence the motion of a dust particle. The MDPX device was designed to do just that – produce a dusty plasma with a strong enough magnetic field to see the effects on dust particles. A superconducting magnet with a magnetic field strength comparable to that used in an MRI device was required for this purpose, and forms the central component of the MDPX.

Almost all of the experimental work on dusty plasmas was performed without magnetic fields. The NSF funded MDPX project was a first attempt to form a magnetized dusty plasma in the laboratory where its properties could be studied. The collaborative work that was funded by NSF focused on understanding the conditions under which a magnetized dusty plasma could be formed in the laboratory. The initial experiments were mainly aimed at observing the effects of forming a dusty plasma under conditions in which only the plasma was strongly influenced by the magnetic field, a condition referred to as strong magnetization. The supporting experiments performed at the University of Iowa plasma laboratory, investigated the effect of a strong magnetic field on the collection of electrons and ions to a small electrode immersed in the plasma. This study has a direct bearing on understanding how magnetized electrons and magnetized ions are collected by a dust particle in a plasma, a crucial issue in determining the dust charge. One of the first (and unexpected) results from the initial MDPX experiments, was the discovery of a phenomenon we called dust gridding, in which the dust particles become spontaneously arranged in a two-dimensional grid-like structure. We have also begun to study how dust sound waves are affected by a strong magnetic field, and the formation of a three-dimensional vortex in a nanometer dusty plasma. The research that was funded by NSF was widely disseminated in presentations given by the PIs and graduate students at various US and international scientific conferences, and was published in peer-reviewed physics journals.

One of the most important broader impacts of this research project was that it was performed as part of the teaching mission of the University. Much of the laboratory work was performed by graduate students as part of their PhD thesis. Thus the project had a direct impact on the development of a well-trained and experienced corps of scientists for the future. The work at the University of Iowa was performed by undergraduate physics majors who were funded by this NSF grant. Providing opportunities for undergraduates to be involved in front-line research greatly increases the chances that they will go on to pursue advanced degrees in physics, engineering, or math. For example, one of the NSF-funded undergraduate students who worked on the University of Iowa magnetized plasma device (Q machine), is now a graduate student in physics at Auburn University doing PhD research on the MDPX device.
